name: 2,4-diphenylisoxazol-5(2H)-one
source: Karthikeyan M.; Glen R.C.; Bender A. General melting point prediction based on a diverse compound dataset and artificial neural networks. J. Chem. Inf. Model.; 2005; 45(3); 581-2874

name: 2,4-diphenylisoxazol-5(2H)-one
source: Karthikeyan M.; Glen R.C.; Bender A. General melting point prediction based on a diverse compound dataset and artificial neural networks. J. Chem. Inf. Model.; 2005; 45(3); 581-2874
Reason: The compound 2,4-diphenylisoxazol-5(2H)-one consists of an isoxazole ring with two phenyl groups attached to it. The basic isoxazole structure (without substituents) has a melting point around 80°C. The two phenyl rings are expected to significantly increase the melting point because they add substantial rigid bulk to the molecule, which increases the van der Waals interactions and molecular stacking, both of which contribute to a higher melting point. Each phenyl group could be estimated to add approximately 40-50°C to the melting point due to these effects. The ketone (carbonyl group) at the 5-position can form strong dipole-dipole interactions and possible hydrogen bonds with other molecules, which can also increase the melting point. The ketone effect might add around 20-30°C. Combining these influences, we arrive at a predicted melting point. The actual value must match the prediction.
